results.title: Winners: Top Kid
results.creator_credit: Carl Schultz, Jane Scott, Bob Ellis, New South Wales Film Corporation, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, ITC Entertainment and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Winners’.
Gary is a bright boy - a bit too bright for his own good, as the other kids try to prove by beating him up regularly after school. Then he goes on a quiz show and suddenly fame and fortune are within his reach… until they start to rig the show and Gary has to make a very difficult decision.

Cast includes Emil Minty, Harold Hopkins, Michelle Fawdon and Garry McDonald.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Carl Schultz, Jane Scott, Bob Ellis, New South Wales Film Corporation, Film Victoria, Australian Film Commission, ITC Entertainment and Australian Children’s Television Foundation

results.title: Green Fingers: Looking After Lemons
results.brief_description:
‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Looking After Lemons’, gardener Rod Cantrill shows ways to look after the popular lemon tree.

The narrator points out various issues that can afflict them including collar rot, leaf yellowing, leaf fall, and pests and diseases, while Cantrill works on lemon trees in a beautiful orchard. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Green Fingers: Indoor Plants
results.brief_description:
‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Indoor Plants’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to propagate and look after indoor plants.

The film contains wonderful footage of the glasshouses at Burnley Horticultural College, with plants shown including rubber plants, philodendron and rex begonias. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Green Fingers: Pest and Disease Control
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: this is an archival film and contemporary advice should be sought when handling chemicals and poisons.

‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Pest and Disease Control’, Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to use agricultural sprays on a rose garden at Burnley Gardens.

Diseases described include black spot, aphids and powdery mildew. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: The Gods of Tiny Things
results.credit_line:
Deborah Kelly

Two-channel digital animation, colour, sound

ACMI Collection

Collage figures: Joanne Albany, Alana Ambados, Kate Andrews, Justin Ashworth, Kathryn Bird, Karen Golland, Amanda Holt, Deborah Kelly, Kath Lim, Lex Lindsay, Megan Rushton, Rie Tamaoke, Anna Tregloan
results.brief_description: Deborah Kelly’s The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopaedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies.

constellations_primary.name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
constellations_primary.description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

results.description:
“This work is blessed by the powers of the animator, musicians and collagists. Having such creative collaborators is the treasure of my life” – Deborah Kelly

The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies. Combining the divine, mundane and profane, these celestial creations animate a kaleidoscopic symbology that explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world, while simultaneously revelling in the persistence of pleasure, desire and life. Created at ‘collage camp’ at Bundanon on beautiful Yuin Country, this collaborative work is a poetic and urgent warning.

Deborah Kelly is a Sydney-based artist whose works have been shown around Australia, and in the Biennales of Singapore, Sydney, Thessaloniki, TarraWarra and Venice. Her projects across media are concerned with lineages of representation, politics and history in public exchange, and practices of collectivity on small and large scale, both fleeting and durational. Her newest works experiment with models of sustained creative collaboration between strangers. Kelly’s moving image artworks have been shown around the world, in galleries, cinemas and projected onto rock formations, buildings and clouds.
description_for_label:

results.title: The Dame Was Loaded [DOS]
results.creator_credit: Philips Interactive Media, Inc. and Beam Software
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. Two CD-ROM, CD case insert and manual in 2 CD capacity jewel case
results.brief_description: The Dame Was Loaded is a detective mystery adventure game reminiscent of private eye movies of the 1940’s. The player controls detective Scott Anger, who is hired by a mysterious woman to find her missing brother, Dan. What at first appears to be just another missing persons case, opens up a much larger web involving Dan’s dark past. The game requires the player to use sleuthing skills to interact with characters, represented by live actors, and solve puzzles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Philips Interactive Media, Inc. and Beam Software

results.title: Shadowrun [SNES]
results.creator_credit: Data East USA and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cartidge videogame. Cartridge, reference sheet and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
The world of Shadowrun is defined by the Awakening, where magic has been re-discovered, and human beings have accepted the existence of those they thought to be fantasy creatures. Mega-corporations and cyberworlds now share the world with elves and Native American shamans.

The player is Jake Armitage, a seemingly ordinary data courier who is assassinated by a hit squad in the year 2050 in Seattle, Washington. A mysterious figure rushes to Jake and cast a spell on him and he wakes up in the morgue with complete memory loss. Jake must now begin to unravel the mystery of his death and miraculous resurrection.

The game is a skill-based role playing game (RPG) with action-oriented combat. The player can use firearms and learn magic spells, primarily with defensive and support capabilities. The game was a critical success, winning a number of industry awards, but was a commercial failure nevertheless. It was retrospectively acclaimed by several publications as an “ahead of its time” milestone in the history of the role-playing genre for the consoles and credited for having pioneered film noir style in video games.

results.title: Powerslide [PC]
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM in CD jewel case with insert and manual
results.brief_description: After an environmental holocaust killed 98% of the world’s population, the survivors above ground turned to modifying and racing the cars left over in the ruins of civilization. In the ruined world of Powerslide, players race through abandoned cities buried in sand, ruins of a dam, abandoned mine shafts, and other desolate landscapes. Perform death-defying jumps and slide through the corners as you eke out each win! This racing sim has full car dynamics, force feedback, and full multiplayer support.
results.description: After an environmental holocaust killed 98% of the world’s population, the survivors above ground turned to modifying and racing the cars left over in the ruins of civilization. results.title: Gumboots Australia [PC]
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. One 3 1/2 inch floppy disk and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Explore Australia and help solve a plethora of mysteries in Gumboots Australia. In this this adventure and educational game, the player is tasked with solving cases as an investigator for the Gumboots Enquiry Agency, a job that will take the player all over the country. The player will get to visit locations as varied as Kakadu to Coober Pedy in their hunt for the next clue. Getting there is its own challenge, as different modes of transportation can cost time and money. Random events along the way aid or hinder the player’s quest to solve the case.

results.title: Flight of the Amazon Queen [DOS]
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert, manual, registration card and installation guide in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Flight of the Amazon Queen is a point and click adventure where you play Joe King as he uses his plane, the Amazon Queen, to fly famous actress Faye Russell to a film shoot. When the plane crash lands in a remote jungle, and he must use his wits to battle his way out of the dangers he faces.

As with many point and click adventures, a set of icons at the bottom of the screen allows the player to interact with other characters or the environment. The game has since been ported to smartphones, with the addition of improved graphics, full voice acting, multi-language support and a play through of the interactive interview mini-game with audio commentary by John Passfield, one of the game’s designers.

Flight of the Amazon Queen is a point and click adventure where you play Joe King as he uses his plane, the Amazon Queen, to fly famous actress Faye Russell to a film shoot. When the plane crash lands in a remote jungle, and he must use his wits to battle his way out of the dangers he faces.

As with many point and click adventures, a set of icons at the bottom of the screen allows the player to interact with other characters or the environment. The game has since been ported to smartphones, with the addition of improved graphics, full voice acting, multi-language support and a play through of the interactive interview mini-game with audio commentary by John Passfield, one of the game’s designers.
